programme.title: The Story of Europe
programme.desc: Europe has been a battle concept for centuries: it often takes foreign enemies to weld the Europeans together. But for centuries, they are primarily fighting against themselves. It was not until the Enlightenment and the French Revolution of 1789 that a new idea of Europe emerged based on common values: freedom, equality and fraternalism.

programme.title: China's Schindlers
programme.desc: These are two stories rarely told that should never be forgotten: The stories of China’s Schindlers - two courageous men who stood up for human decency as evil engulfed the world. Chinese diplomat Dr. Feng Shan Ho was Consul-General in Vienna, Austria in the late 1930s. Disturbed by the Nazis’ persecution of Viennese Jews, Feng Shan Ho gave visas to Jews desperate enough to escape Hitler, and that allowed them to immigrate to Shanghai when no other nation would accept them. German businessman John Rabe lived in China for 30 years. In 1937, after Japanese troops invaded his adopted city of Nanking, Rabe could not bear to witness the horrors and atrocities around him. Under the protection of the Nazi flag, he led the establishment of a Safety Zone protecting 200,000 innocent Chinese. Diaries & letters left behind are among some of the only evidence left of those who endured unspeakable horrors and bravely sacrificed for their fellow man. Those diaries, along with the voices of survivors tell not only of the darkness and terror, but also of the heroism, bravery and sacrifice of a few individuals whose character and courage stand as beacons of the human spirit. We illustrate the complex nature of the political positions of Germany, Japan, and China during WWII, highlighting Germany's acknowledgement of its wartime actions in an effort to heal relationships with the Jewish people and other neighboring countries. Experts discuss the positive impact that this has had on Germany socially and economically and how this strategy could benefit the Japanese and Chinese economic partnership and promote friendship in future generations. The West often overlooks China in the story of WWII. The Chinese people suffered horrors and atrocities that still haunt survivors. They bear witness to past brutality and endure emotional wounds that have never healed.

programme.title: The Battle for the Baltic Sea
programme.desc: It’s in spring 2008, when the telephone of the Archaeological State Office Schleswig-Holstein suddenly rings. The message archeologist Martin Segschneider receives makes him curious.

programme.title: The Secret File of Marco Polo
programme.desc: Did Marco Polo, the most illustrious traveller in history, ever go to China? A dispute lingers to this day; with some scholars still doubting whether the Venetian’s book is a genuine personal account of China’s 13th-century Middle Kingdom and its marvels. Scientists, western scholars and Chinese historians have uncovered striking new proof that the son of Venetian merchants actually had been in China. We accompany them on their quest from Venice to Beijing, to Yangzhou and Quanzhou, from the gravestones of Italian merchant families to Chinese chronicles documenting the presence of one ‘Boluo’ at the imperial court, to famous buildings described by Marco Polo and to the ‘salt men’ of China who still apply the techniques that were used seven hundred years ago. This is a journey of opulent vistas, re-enacting Marco Polo’s experiences in 13th-century China and sheds light on the pivotal role, played by an obscure writer of chivalric novels, in producing the manuscript of the Travels of Marco Polo.

programme.title: Russia's Hidden Paradises
programme.desc: Russia is one of the most diverse and by far the largest country in the world. Its immense nature has always fascinated people. There are more than one hundred nature reserves, national parks and biosphere reserves between the lowlands in the west and the Mountains of fire on Kamchatka in the east.

programme.title: Mountains
programme.desc: A mother lynx feeds on freshly caught prey with her cubs, agile chamoix leap along mountain ledges, bee-eaters dig nesting holes in vineyards, black storks bring up their young on narrow ridges.

programme.title: Forests
programme.desc: Shrouded in myth and legend, the forests of Germany are world famous, thanks to the fairy tales of the Brothers Grimm. The strange creatures that actually live there are shown in the episode Forests of the four-part series Wild Germany.

programme.title: Rivers and Lakes
programme.desc: Water is the beginning of all life - including the wildlife of Germany. Beavers fell trees, otters play under water, kingfishers catch fish for their young. Lakes and rivers cover just 2.5% of the total area of the country. The episode Rivers and Lakes takes the viewer on a journey through the water world of Germany.

programme.title: The Mediterranean South
programme.desc: From the dreamlike Mediterranean and spectacular canyon landscapes of Andalusia, to the expanses of the Extremadura with its holm oak forests that stretch toward the horizon. Even in the south of Spain, highly popular with holidaymakers, there is still much waiting to be discovered. Genets hunt for prey under cover of night.

programme.title: Mountains
programme.desc: A mother lynx feeds on freshly caught prey with her cubs, agile chamoix leap along mountain ledges, bee-eaters dig nesting holes in vineyards, black storks bring up their young on narrow ridges.

programme.title: Forests
programme.desc: Shrouded in myth and legend, the forests of Germany are world famous, thanks to the fairy tales of the Brothers Grimm. The strange creatures that actually live there are shown in the episode Forests of the four-part series Wild Germany.

programme.title: The Colors of the Desert
programme.desc: More than one-hundred-million years ago, the Colorado Plateau was an inland sea. Today it is a red desert. The Colorado River, which gives the desert its name, has so deeply bored into the earth, that it can no longer irrigate the land along its banks.

programme.title: The Colors of the Desert
programme.desc: The Gray Mojave in California is an endless, rutted and mountainous landscape with vast gravel fields and little sand. A desert whipped to roughness by the wind. Its pale gray can become intensely dark, or, chameleon-like, change its hue to match the varying seasons or daylight.

programme.title: Ambitions and Conquests
programme.desc: From the 15th to well into the 20th century, Europeans conquered and dominated the world: On behalf of the Spaniards, Christopher Columbus seeks a new sea route to India and finds a "New World": America! His discovery is the starting signal for the "Europeanization of the Earth".

programme.title: The Story of Europe
programme.desc: Europe's history has many dark sides, but its culture is more than a small gleam of hope, it radiates in many areas far out into the world. The old continent sets standards in art, literature and science. Starting with the ancient Greeks, Europe produces a number of smart and creative minds: from Aristotle to Michelangelo and Einstein, from Beethoven to the Beatles.

programme.title: Europe in the Middle Ages
programme.desc: Most of the population in the Middle Ages lived on the land - a silent, suffering majority, who as serfs had to do soccage service and pay taxes to the ruling noblemen and were repeatedly exposed to famine and violent conflicts.

programme.title: Europe in the Middle Ages
programme.desc: Historians for a long time considered the picturesque maze of alleyways in mediaeval towns to be construction planning gone haywire. New research reveals the surprising fact that many mediaeval towns were conceived on the drawing board by urban planners who were well versed in geometry, for the towns grew and offered a home to many people.
